III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
A. Physical Description of Facility
Both male houses are located on the west side of the center of campus. Ashmun and
Sherk share housing designs wherein each house is a one-story, ranch-style home with
a basement. The basement is used for group activities, for storage, for doing laundry,
and as a “mud room” for shoes, coats, etc. Each house has a kitchen and a dining area
where the youths eat breakfast, weekend meals, and other meals during times when the
main campus dining area is closed (Ashmun youths eat all of their meals at the house).
Each house has a day area/living room and a bathroom. The sleeping area is in line-of-
site of the day area, and consists of seven bedrooms. Two youths sleep in each room,
and the additional bedroom is used for storing clothing. Each bedroom contains
shelves for clothing, a bunk bed and a desk. In addition there is a House Supervisor’s
office and a storage room for toiletries, first aid and medications.
B. Program Description
The residential older boys program consists of two separate houses – Ashmun House,
which serves an abuse/neglect population, and Sherk House, which serves a
delinquency population. The residential program serves male youths ages 12 to17 in
Sherk House, and ages 13 to 16 in Ashmun House. These youths are struggling with
2

emotional and behavioral issues to the extent that the youth, the family and/or the
community have been negatively impacted, resulting in the youth being removed from
the home and the community.
The program accepts youths from the following.
• DHS Delinquents.
• DHS County offices (abuse/neglect).
• County Court referrals.
• Adoption Subsidy referrals.
• Private referrals.
• School Referrals.
Residential programming is designed to meet the psychological, emotional, behavioral
and spiritual needs of the youth and family. This is done through the following services:
• Individual/group/family counseling.
• Experiential programming including a 12-day wilderness program, weekend
wilderness programs, community service programs and ropes and towers
initiatives.
• Substance abuse counseling groups (when necessary).
• Psychiatric evaluation (when necessary).
• Psychological testing (when necessary).
• Life skills.
• Educational programming.
• Home visits.
• Voluntary chapel programming including chapel services, youth groups, and
spiritual counseling.
Residents attend year round schooling with on-campus school staff through the
Mecosta/Osceola School District. Each classroom is staffed with one special education
teacher and one teacher’s aide. Youth Counselors, House Supervisors and other
personnel provide additional supervision if necessary.
Each house has two Family Counselors who develop and manage the overall treatment
of the youths. The Family Counselors are responsible for providing individual, group
and family counseling, and are an integral part of the experiential programming.
Treatment is provided using the cognitive-behavioral and experiential approaches.
There is also a point/level and token economy system that is used primarily as a daily
behavior management tool.
Youths in Ashmun, the abuse/neglect house, tend to stay in care longer than the youths
in Sherk, the delinquency house. Discharge from the program can occur through
Graduation, Escalation, Truancy or Maximum Benefit. With a discharge due to
Graduation, Escalation or Maximum benefit, the date of termination is established at
least 30 days prior to release, so that transitional counseling and maximizing community
support services can occur.

C. Rule/Statutory Violations
The Eagle Village Ashmun-Sherk program was reviewed as part of the overall Eagle
Village, Inc. residential licensing review conducted February 5 and 6 and March 6,
2007. All identified rule violations have been corrected, and the facility is in compliance
with all applicable rule areas.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
It is recommended that an Original Provisional License be issued, effective 9/4/2007.
